title: Are Alaskans really Native Americans? - Quora
tags: History of the United States of America

response.answer_text: Perhaps the question would be better if it asked, Are Alaskans Indigenous people? The perceived pejorative term Indians, was replaced by what was thought better as in Native Americans. Some now prefer indigenous people, ‘meaning “the native or original inhabitants of the Americas”. The truth is, that most indigenous people have their own language name such as the Dine, who we call Navajo, or Iswa, who we call Catawba. Alaska’s indigenous people are several different tribes, including, Aleut, Inuit, Tlingit, Haida, Tsimshian, Eyak, and a number of Northern Athabasca cultures. Alaska’s first people number about 119,241 (as of the 2000 census). There are 229 federally recognized Alaskan villages and five unrecognized Tlingit Alaskan Indian tribes. The debate as to whether they crossed from Siberia, or up through Tierra del Fuego, or even by boat from Polynesia, are theories unproven. However, having worked with forensic anthropologists, I can say that the skeletal remains of indigenous people are unique, and can be readily identified. The cranial structure is different from people descended from white Europeans.

I am a Native American, I am pretty sure I'm 100% white but I was born in America and have lived here my whole life. That makes me a native. As too your question I’m sure you mean the various ethnic groups that inhabited the Americas before Europeans. And the Inuit ethnic group has inhabited Alaska for thousands of years so yes the are. Are all Alaskans part of the Inuit group? No. Yet all those born in the Americas are native to America.

The study of Native American populations is technically very challenging because of the widespread occurrence of European and African mixture in Native American groups. Yes, they are related. It is thought from genetic and other evidence that the Native people from Alaska, Canada and Greenland in the north to Tierra del Fuego in South America came in at least three waves. Eskimo-Aleut-Inuit-Yupik speakers are the last wave and they derive about 57% of their DNA from First Americans. As for why the Inuit-Eskimo don’t want to be called “Indian” or “Native American”, it is a cultural issue. They have and had different cultures. Having a different culture is not about “being related”

Alaska Native and Native Alaskan have distinct meanings. True story. I can lay claim to the latter title easily- I was born here. I am a native Alaskan. But I’m not Alaska Native. My ancestors were overwhelmingly of European descent, both of my parents were born in California, and so on. Alaska Native is a specific designation based on ethnic, linguistic, and cultural heritage, and no matter how many potlatches I attend or how many invitationals I dance, it is not a designation I can- or should- ever earn.

I live in Alaska. There are many Native Americans living here. Also many many more races of people. Only 700,000 live here. Alaska is 2.5 times larger than Texas. The Native Americans who live here are unique, and brave people. For thousands of years they survived here in some of the harshest weather on the planet. I am just an everyday red neck white guy.
Groups in Alaska, such as the Inuit, who were in the Americas before 1492 are Native Americans. Groups which came later - whites, blacks, etc, are not.
